Comment: He’s such an asshole…  President Trump signed an executive order seeking to end federal funding for NPR and PBS.   Proportion of Federal Funding in Budgets  - PBS: With a total budget of approximately $2.65 billion, the $397 million in federal funding represents about 15% of its annual revenue.  - NPR: NPR’s total budget is around $314 million, making the $132 million in federal funding about 42% of its annual revenue.  However, here’s the key legal and financial reality:  Executive Orders vs. Congressional Authority  - CPB Funding is Appropriated by Congress The Corporation for Public Broadcasting (CPB) receives its funding through Congressional appropriations, not presidential discretion.  That means:  - The President cannot unilaterally cut funding—Congress controls the budget.  - An executive order may direct federal agencies to withhold cooperation or urge future defunding, but it cannot cancel already-appropriated funds.  - Legal Challenges Likely  This action will almost certainly face legal opposition (as it did in prior administrations when funding cuts were proposed but never fully enacted). The CPB’s charter and bipartisan support for local public stations make blanket defunding politically and legally complex.  Bottom Line:  While the image captures a bold political move, the actual funding impact depends on Congress and the courts. As of the 2024 fiscal year:  - CPB still received $525 million.  - PBS funding accounted for ~15% of its budget.  - NPR, via local stations, relied on federal dollars for ~42% of its total revenue path.
